Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I noticed lately that my parents have been quieter, their faces drawn with worry lines that weren’t there before. At dinner, my mom barely touched her food, and my dad kept sighing, lost in thought. I know they need me now, maybe more than ever, to sit with them, listen, and just be present. But this Sunday, like every week, my church expects me to be there—worshipping, volunteering, connecting with my faith community. I believe in the importance of being part of the church, not just for myself but as a way to serve God. Yet, as I watch my parents, I feel torn. If I stay home, I can comfort them, maybe ease their burden a little. If I go to church, I honor my commitment to my faith and my community. The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I find myself caught in the middle, heart aching, unsure which path to take.
